Article:
Hey folks, I am going to apply for a job as front end web developer in a company for which resume is... Tagged with discuss, webdeveloper, javascript.
Ubaid Sid
Posted on Aug 19, 2019
How to write a Frontend Web Developer Resume?
# discuss # webdeveloper # javascript
Hey folks, I am going to apply for a job as front end web developer in a company for which resume is required. Do you have any advice on resume for entry level developer applying for first time?
(14)
The first rule of resume - don't write every language/technology you've ever heard/studied about. Just don't.
It will show them that you wrote everything from some example resume and don't know any of them actually. Write only those things you know and you are interested in (if you can answer questions about them in the interview!). Remember that recruiter may ask you about anything that you wrote. If you know CSS but you will write that you know SCSS they can ask you about example mixins you created or what's the difference between them with examples. If you don't answer - well, most likely you won't get a job as you didn't tell truth in resume.
Oh, and don't write that you know Word/Excel/Paint, etc. You can basically recognise entry-level CVs thanks to that - I've seen it too many times.
Write a simple resume which will actually sum up your skills. I would rather hire a person (entry-level) with 3-4 skills in a CV that can be proven than with 15 skills and almost no proof. In "about me" section - if you are going to add it - you can add that you are interested in XYZ in your free time. It will show them you are interested and ambitious, you don't know this yet but there is potential :)
I can totally recommend canva.com for writing resume. It's free and has PDF export. Templates are clear, simple and look professional.
Good luck with that job 🤞
I would like to double down on not putting every language/technology you've ever heard or studied about. To many times I would see someone who listed every language from Front-End to Back-End because they read about it once, then I would ask a simple question about CSS and they would not be able answer it. Like Natalia said if you can answer questions or at least be able to carry a conversation on about the language/technology then add it to your resume.
All around I wish I took this advice when I first started would have made interviews a lot easier going forward.
Best of luck!
I was going make this mistake of writing all skills and sub-skills in my resume. I thought that would make a good impression on my interviewer, but your point has made me avoid doing that.
Glad we could help you :D Leave a note later if you got the job! :)
I think Frontend Web Developer Resume is the same as any other Developer Resume.
Usually, you divide resume into sections, here is an example used by me:
Contact data
name
email
phone number
Linkedin/Github profile
Personal Profile (Write something about you. What you like about programming, hobbies ...)
Education (descendent order by time):
2017-2019: Uni, Bachelor of Computer Science
2015-2017: College, Computer Science
Experience (descendent order by time):
Web app for Uni course: My team was aggregating a public gov API and my task was the website that displays external debt of Country in a friendly way. I created a small VueJS app with FLUX Architecture. | Link to Github repo
Chatbot: Using Facebook API I created a chatbot that message uni schedule, every evening and morning. I used NodeJS and ... | Link to Github repo
mOcKiNgCaSe: npm package that converts a string to mOcKiNgCaSe. Contribution: Added "onlyLetters" option. | Link to Github repo
Skills
Development: JavaScript/TypeScript (proficient), Version control/GIT (proficient), HTML/CSS (working knowledge), Python (basic knowledge)
Languages: Romanian (native), English (fluent), Russian (fluent), German (beginner)
Thanks Dragos. Is photo necessary on resume?
No, I would suggest to not attach the photo
why?
If you have a good photo (taken by a photographer) that will make your CV look better then put it. Otherwise don't.
Keep your known languages and libraries focused on the things you know.
Ask yourself to explain the languages and libraries you know, you'll find any gaps you might have and what level of experience you have when it comes up.
Research on these gaps, you don't want to be stuck getting asked: "Can you define OOP?" without an answer.
Proofread for any typos or mistakes. Written and verbal communication is more important than people think as a developer, and this can give off a less than good first impression.
Remember all the things you put down on your resume, sometimes it can be too easy to jot something down and forget about it. You don't want to get blind-sighted by your own resume.
Bonus Make a small, simple, nice looking portfolio site and leave a link on your resume. Especially as a front end developer, it's a nice addition that shows you know the basics o...(Truncated)


Elaborate on the benefits of using canva.com for resume creation.

<finish> Canva.com is a popular online design and publishing tool that offers a wide range of features and benefits for creating resumes, especially for those who may not have extensive graphic design experience. Here are some of the key benefits of using Canva for resume creation:

1. User-Friendly Interface: Canva has an intuitive drag-and-drop interface that makes it easy for users to design and customize their resumes without needing any prior design knowledge.

2. Professional Templates: Canva provides a vast library of professionally designed resume templates that users can choose from. These templates cater to different job industries and styles, ensuring that there's something suitable for everyone.

3. Customization Options: Users can easily customize templates by changing fonts, colors, and layout. They can also add elements such as icons, shapes, and lines to enhance the visual appeal of their resumes.

4. Access to a Rich Media Library: Canva offers a large collection of stock photos, illustrations, and icons that can be used to add visual interest to a resume. Many of these elements are free, while some premium options are available for a small fee.

5. Branding Consistency: For those looking to maintain a consistent personal brand, Canva allows users to upload their own logos, images, and other branding elements to incorporate into their resume design.

6. Collaboration: Canva enables users to collaborate with others by sharing their resume design. This is particularly useful for getting feedback from mentors, peers, or professional resume writers.

7. Cross-Platform Accessibility: Canva can be accessed from any web browser, and it also offers mobile apps for iOS and Android devices. This means users can work on their resumes from anywhere and at any time.

8. PDF Export: Once the resume is complete, Canva allows users to download it in various formats, including PDF, which is the preferred format for many employers because it maintains the design and layout of the document.

9. Regular Updates: Canva frequently updates its platform with new features, templates, and design elements, ensuring that users have access to the latest design trends and tools.

10. Cost-Effective: Canva offers a free version with a wide range of features that are sufficient for creating a basic yet professional-looking resume. For more advanced features, users can opt for a paid subscription, which is still relatively affordable compared to hiring a professional designer.

Overall, Canva.com provides an accessible, cost-effective, and comprehensive solution for creating a visually appealing and professional resume that can help job seekers stand out in a competitive job market. </finish>

### Task:
A metal plate with variable dimensions and shape (square or rectangular) is initially at a uniform temperature. Each side of the plate can have different boundary conditions: maintained at a certain temperature, insulated, or exposed to an environment with a known convective heat transfer coefficient. Given the properties of the metal (thermal conductivity, density, specific heat), the thickness of the plate, and a specific grid spacing, calculate the steady-state temperature distribution across the plate using the finite difference method. Scenarios should include different shapes, sizes, boundary conditions, materials, and points of interest for temperature calculation.

Example 1

Q:
A rectangular bronze plate with dimensions of 25 cm by 40 cm and a thickness of 3 mm is exposed to the following boundary conditions: the left side is insulated, the right side is maintained at 150°C, the top side is exposed to an environment with a convective heat transfer coefficient of 30 W/m²K and an ambient temperature of 25°C, and the bottom side is maintained at 75°C. The thermal conductivity of bronze is 116 W/mK, the density is 8800 kg/m³, and the specific heat is 377 J/kgK. Calculate the steady-state temperature at a point located 10 cm from the left side and 20 cm from the bottom side using a grid spacing of 4 cm.

A:
{"specified_point_temperature": 107.8}

Example 2

Q:
A rectangular steel plate with dimensions of 20 cm by 30 cm and a thickness of 5 mm has the following boundary conditions: all sides are maintained at 200°C. The thermal conductivity of steel is 50 W/mK, the density is 7850 kg/m³, and the specific heat is 500 J/kgK. Calculate the steady-state temperature at a point located 5 cm from the left side and 10 cm from the bottom side using a grid spacing of 5 cm.

A:
{"specified_point_temperature": 200.0}

Example 3

Q:
A square copper plate with a side length of 15 cm and a thickness of 1 mm is exposed to the following boundary conditions: the left side is maintained at 0°C, the right side is exposed to an environment with a convective heat transfer coefficient of 10 W/m²K and an ambient temperature of 30°C, the top side is insulated, and the bottom side is maintained at 100°C. The thermal conductivity of copper is 401 W/mK, the density is 8960 kg/m³, and the specific heat is 385 J/kgK. Calculate the steady-state temperature at a point located 7.5 cm from the left side and 7.5 cm from the bottom side using a grid spacing of 3 cm.

A:
{"specified_point_temperature": 55.2}

Example 4

Q:
A square titanium plate with a side length of 5 cm and a thickness of 0.5 mm is exposed to the following boundary conditions: the left side is maintained at 50°C, the right side is maintained at 0°C, the top side is insulated, and the bottom side is exposed to an environment with a convective heat transfer coefficient of 5 W/m²K and an ambient temperature of 20°C. The thermal conductivity of titanium is 22 W/mK, the density is 4500 kg/m³, and the specific heat is 520 J/kgK. Calculate the steady-state temperature at the four corners of the plate using a grid spacing of 1 cm.

A:
{
  "top_left_corner_temperature": 50.0,
  "top_right_corner_temperature": 0.0,
  "bottom_left_corner_temperature": 35.7,
  "bottom_right_corner_temperature": 10.4
}

Example 5

Q:
A square aluminum plate with a side length of 10 cm and a thickness of 2 mm is exposed to the following boundary conditions: the left side is maintained at 100°C, the right side is insulated, the top side is exposed to an environment with a convective heat transfer coefficient of 25 W/m²K and an ambient temperature of 20°C, and the bottom side is maintained at 50°C. The thermal conductivity of aluminum is 205 W/mK, the density is 2700 kg/m³, and the specific heat is 897 J/kgK. Calculate the steady-state temperature at the center of the plate using a grid spacing of 2 cm.

A:

### Task:
You are tasked with creating a collection of logic puzzles that revolve around the concept of time. These puzzles should help students understand how to read clocks, calculate time intervals, and comprehend schedules and time zones.

Requirements:
1. Develop puzzles that involve reading analog and digital clocks to determine the time.
2. Create scenarios where students must calculate the duration between two events or times.
3. Include puzzles that require understanding and working with different time formats, such as 12-hour and 24-hour clocks.
4. Design word problems that involve planning schedules, considering time zones, and calculating arrival or departure times.
5. The puzzles should vary in complexity, introducing concepts such as daylight saving time, international time zones, and the calculation of time differences across cities or countries.

Provide examples of each type of puzzle, along with a clear explanation of the thought process and solution.

Example 1
Input:
A flight departs New York at 3:00 PM EST and arrives in Los Angeles at 6:00 PM PST. Considering the time zone difference, how long is the flight?

Output:
To calculate the flight duration, we must account for the time zone difference between New York (EST) and Los Angeles (PST), which is 3 hours, with New York being ahead. The flight departs at 3:00 PM EST; at that moment, it is 12:00 PM PST in Los Angeles. The flight arrives at 6:00 PM PST. To find the duration, we calculate the time from 12:00 PM to 6:00 PM, which is 6 hours. Therefore, the flight duration is 6 hours.

Example 2
Input:
Convert 4:00 PM to 24-hour format and then determine what time it will be 5 hours later.

Output:
To convert the time from 12-hour to 24-hour format, we add 12 to the PM hours. Therefore, 4:00 PM becomes 16:00 in 24-hour format. To find out what time it will be 5 hours later, we add 5 to the hour part of the time: 16 + 5 = 21. Thus, the time 5 hours later is 21:00, which is equivalent to 9:00 PM in 12-hour format.

Example 3
Input:
If a movie starts at 7:45 PM and ends at 9:30 PM, how long is the movie?

Output:
To calculate the duration of the movie, we need to find the time difference between the start and end times. We start by finding the difference in hours: from 7:45 PM to 8:45 PM is one hour. Then, we calculate the remaining minutes from 8:45 PM to 9:30 PM, which is 45 minutes. By adding the one hour to the 45 minutes, we get the total duration of the movie, which is 1 hour and 45 minutes.

Example 4
Input:
An analog clock shows the hour hand on the 3 and the minute hand on the 6. What time is it?

Output:
To determine the time on an analog clock, we look at the positions of the hour and minute hands. The hour hand is pointing directly at the 3, which indicates the hour. The minute hand is pointing at the 6, and since each number on the clock represents 5 minutes, the 6 corresponds to 30 minutes (6 times 5 minutes). Therefore, the time displayed on the clock is 3:30.

Example 5
Input:
A meeting is scheduled for 10:00 AM in London. If you are in Tokyo, where the local time is 9 hours ahead of London, what time should you join the meeting?

Output:

<finish> To determine the time you should join the meeting in Tokyo, we add the time difference to the London time. Since Tokyo is 9 hours ahead, we add 9 hours to 10:00 AM. This calculation results in 19:00, or 7:00 PM. Therefore, you should join the meeting at 7:00 PM Tokyo time. </finish>
A meeting is scheduled to start at 2:45 PM and the end time is automatically set to 1 hour later. However, the meeting actually ends at 4:30 PM. How long did the meeting last?

<finish> The meeting was scheduled to start at 2:45 PM and was supposed to last for 1 hour, which would make the scheduled end time 3:45 PM. However, the meeting actually ended at 4:30 PM.

To calculate the actual duration of the meeting, we can subtract the start time from the end time:

End time: 4:30 PM
Start time: 2:45 PM

From 2:45 PM to 3:45 PM is 1 hour.
From 3:45 PM to 4:30 PM is another 45 minutes.

So, the total duration of the meeting is 1 hour + 45 minutes = 1 hour and 45 minutes.

The meeting lasted for 1 hour and 45 minutes. </finish>

You are an expert text classifier. You need to classify the text below into one of the given classes. 

Text:

In a multinational diplomatic negotiation, countries receive confidential strategy outlines from a neutral international facilitator. The strategic correlation equilibrium is achieved when each country acts in accordance with the facilitator's confidential strategy, understanding that any departure from this coordinated plan would not enhance their own geopolitical position, given the presumption of mutual adherence to the strategy among the negotiating countries.

Classes:

Simultaneous Move Nash Equilibrium;Feedback Nash Equilibrium;Minimax Equilibrium in Zero-Sum Games;Sequential Move Leadership Equilibrium;Strategic Correlation Equilibrium;Incomplete Information Nash Equilibrium;Evolutionarily Stable Equilibrium;Markovian Dynamic Strategic Equilibrium;Stochastic Choice Equilibrium;Stag Hunt Coordination Equilibrium;Pareto Efficiency Equilibrium;Non-standard Equilibrium Dynamics;Non-equilibrium Context

The output format must be:

Final class: {selected_class}
